title: Early 2007: Satoshi starts working on bitcoin
paragraphs: Satoshi Nakamoto starts writing code for Bitcoin. This is based on a post to the Cryptography mailing list where Satoshi wrote on Nov 17th, 2008:
»I believe I've worked through all those little details over the last year and a half while coding it.«

title: 1st November 2008: Bitcoin paper published
paragraphs: Satoshi Nakamoto announces Bitcoin on the Cryptography mailing list:
»I've been working on a new electronic cash system that's fully peer-to-peer, with no trusted third party.«
Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System

title: Between 3rd and 9th January 2009: Genesis Block minted
paragraphs: The Genesis block is mined with a timestamp of Jan 9th.
The coinbase containing the famouse words: »The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor on brink of second bailout for banks«.

title: 9th January 2009: Bitcoin v0.1 is announced
paragraphs: Satoshi Nakamoto writes on the cryptography mailing list:
»Announcing the first release of Bitcoin, a new electronic cash system that uses a peer-to-peer network to prevent double-spending. It's completely decentralized with no server or central authority.

title: 16th December 2009: Bitcoin v0.2.0 released
paragraphs: A user called Martti Malmi (sirius-m) adds initial support for Linux. Other new features include mining on multiple CPU cores and initial tor proxy support.

title: 6th July 2010: Bitcoin v0.3.0 released
paragraphs: Laszlo Hanyecz (Bitcoin pizza guy) adds support for macOS. Other new features include the JSON-RPC interface and a new daemon mode. Users contribute GUI translations into German, Dutch and Italian.

title: 15th July 2010: Bitcoin v0.3.1 released (bugfix)
paragraphs: Miscellaneous bugs get fixed. Gavin Andresen starts contributing.

title: 17th July 2010: Bitcoin v0.3.2 released
paragraphs: Satoshi adds checkpoints as a security safeguard that locks a block height to a specific hash. He writes:

»I'll probably put a checkpoint in each version from now on.  Once the software has settled what the widely accepted block chain is, there's no point in leaving open the unwanted non-zero possibility of revision months later.«

title: 25th July 2010: Bitcoin v0.3.3 released
paragraphs: This release includes the first consensus change.
The Bitcoin software now follows the chain with the most accumulated work. Prior to that it followed the longest chain - the chain with the most blocks.

title: Throughout the sommer of 2010
paragraphs: Various Bitcoin v0.3.xx versions are released.

title: 15th August 2010: Critical overflow bug fixed
paragraphs: Satoshi pushes out a fix in v0.3.9(ish) and tells users and miners to re-org the block with the overflowed transaction out of history.

title: 22nd August 2010: Alert system introduced
paragraphs: Satoshi starts working on an alert system which is added in v0.3.11. He writes:
»I've been working on writing the alert system.  Alerts are broadcast through the network and apply to a range of version numbers.  Alert messages are signed with a private key that only I have.«
»Getting surprised by some temporary down time when your node would otherwise be at risk is better than getting surprised by a thief draining all your inventory.«

»Someday when we haven't found any new bugs for a long time and it has been thoroughly security reviewed without finding anything, this can be scaled back.  I'm not arguing that this is the permanent way of things forever.  It's still beta software.«

title: 12th December 2010: Final post from Satoshi
paragraphs: Final post from Satoshi to bitcointalk.org. He adds some DoS limits and removes the previously introduced alert system safe mode.
»There's more work to do on DoS, but I'm doing a quick build of what I have so far in case it's needed, before venturing into more complex ideas.  The build for this is version 0.3.19.«

title: 19th December 2010: Development moves to GitHub
paragraphs: Active development and issue tracking of Bitcoin moves to GitHub.

title: 23th April 2011: Last contact with Satoshi
paragraphs: Alleged final email from Satoshi to Mike Hearn:
»I've moved on to other things.  It's in good hands with Gavin and everyone.«

title: March-June 2011: New contributors join
paragraphs: New contributors start working on the project. Some of them are for example TheBlueMatt (March 3), sipa (March 12), laanwj (May 15) and gmaxwell (June 18). Their first pull requests are listed below.

title: 19th August 2011: First BIP
paragraphs: With 'BIP 1: BIP Purpose and Guidelines' the first Bitcoin Improvement Proposal is created.

title: 23th September 2011: Bitcoin v0.4 released
paragraphs: Version v0.4. is released with the main feature being wallet encryption.

title: 21th November 2011: Bitcoin-QT v0.5. released
paragraphs: Features are a the new qt GUI and a major bug fix for the wallet encryption (CVE-2011-4447).

title: November 2011 - April 2012: Work on P2SH and other
paragraphs: Work on various proposals (OP_EVAL/P2SH/OP_CHV) to allow the receiver of a transaction to specify the script needed to spend it.
P2SH choosen to be implemented in Bitcoin-Qt v0.5.4. Both other proposals are discarded.

title: 30th March 2012: Bitcoin-QT v0.6 released
paragraphs: Features include are for example QR codes for addresses, a implementaion of BIP30 (a security fix for an attack involving duplicate coinbase transactions) and fixes for memory related denial-of-service attacks.

title: 17th September 2012: Bitcoin-QT v0.7 released
paragraphs: Includes implemention of BIP 22, BIP 34 and BIP 35 and additonally a lot of changes in the GUI and for the networking RPC code.

title: 27th September 2012: Bitcoin Foundation announced
paragraphs: Gavin Andresen announces the Bitcoin Foundation. People fear that the foundation will lead to a centralization of Bitcoin.

title: 19th February 2013: Bitcoin-QT v0.8 released
paragraphs: This release migrates the blockchain storage from BerkleyDB to LevelDB. Additionally the UTXO-set or chainstate is seperated from the blocks by a functionallity called ultraprune developed by sipa (Pieter Wuillie).

title: 11th March 2013: Unexpected hardfork
paragraphs: A unexpected hardfork occured where pre-v0.8 nodes forked of v0.8 nodes.

title: 12th December 2013: Rebranding to Bitcoin Core
paragraphs: The Bitcoin-Qt software is rebranded to Bitcoin Core.

title: 19th March 2014: Bitcoin Core v0.9 released
paragraphs: New features include OP_RETURN as a way to include data in blockchain while marking the UTXOs as unspendable. Additionally autotools is now used as the build system, bitcoin-cli is introduced as a RPC-client to communicate to the bitcoind deamon.

title: Sometime in 2014: Chaincode Labs funded
paragraphs: Alex Morcos and Suhas Daftuar found Chiancode Labs in 2014 to create a place for engineers and scientists to support the development of decentralized digital currencies.

title: 23th October 2014: Blockstream founded
paragraphs: Adam Back, Matt Corallo, Greg Maxwell, Pieter Wuille et al. found Blockstream and release their sidechains whitepaper.

title: 16th Febuary 2015: Bitcoin Core v0.10.0 released.
paragraphs: Notable features include headers-first synchronization, the REST interface, the bitcoin-tx utility to create and manipulate transactions and a lot more.

title: 15th April 2015: MIT DCI founded
paragraphs: The MIT Media Lab launches the Digital Currency Initiative (DCI). DCI is a research community focused on cryptocurrency and blockchain technology.

links.label: Launching a Digital Currency Initiative on Medium

title: 12th July 2015: Bitcoin Core v0.11.0 released
paragraphs: The release includes block file pruning as one of its main features.

title: 14th January 2016: Lightning whitepaper released
paragraphs: Joseph Poon and Thaddeus Dryja release the Lightning Whitepaper.
The Bitcoin Lightning Network: Scalable Off-Chain Instant Payments

title: 3rd Febrary 2016: BIP 2 created
paragraphs: Luke Dashjr creates BIP2 in which he proposed a more well-defined and clear BIP process. The proposal is adoped by the community.

title: 23th February 2016: Bitcoin Core v0.12.0 released.
paragraphs: Major features are the introduction of libsecp, sendheaders, opt-in RBF (BIP 125) and mempool limiting.

title: 15th April 2016: Bitcoin Core v0.12.1 released
paragraphs: This release includes the BIP 9 versionbits logic and the definition for the OP_CHECKSEQUENCEVERIFY soft fork.

title: 23th August 2016: Bitcoin Core v0.13.0 released
paragraphs: Includes preparatory changes for segwit, Compact blocks, mempool fee-based filtering, HD wallet support, and CPFP transaction selection

title: 27th October 2016: Bitcoin Core v0.13.1 released
paragraphs: This release includes the code for SegWit as a softfork.

title: 1st November 2016: Alert System Retirement
paragraphs: The network wide alert system, which represents a large source of centralization in Bitcoin, is being retired.

title: 8th March 2017: Bitcoin Core v0.14 released
paragraphs: This release significantly speeds up the initial block download.

title: 14th September 2017: v0.15 released
paragraphs: This release includes a better fee estimates, support for fee bumping in the GUI, multiwallet functionallity and the script cache.

title: 11th November 2017: v0.15.1 released
paragraphs: This release focuses on the safety of the P2P network as a precaution against potential future network forks, as well as bringing bug fixes, optimisations and improvements to the 0.15.x series.

title: 24th August 2017: SegWit activated
paragraphs: SegWit gets activated on Bitcoin mainnet.

title: 26th February 2018: Bitcoin Core v0.16 released
paragraphs: This release mainly adds SegWit support to the Bitcoin Core wallet.

title: 3rd October 2018: Bitcoin Core v0.18.0 released
paragraphs: This release adds features to the wallet. One being support for Partially Signed Bitcoin Transactions (PSBT).

title: 2nd May 2019: Bitcoin Core v0.18.0 released
paragraphs: This release includes a lot of new features and small changes.

title: 6th May 2019: Taproot proposed
paragraphs: Pieter Wuille proposes taproot which brings improvements to privacy, efficiency, and flexibility of Bitcoin smart contracts.
